150984362.review:
I love this game in so many ways, the story is great, the characters are endearing at times and somewhat superficial in others but that would be expected from androids, the dialogues are engaging and unexpected sometimes and the voice acting is perfect, the futuristic setting is well conceived, the ambient lighting and sound effects all very good and the graphics are great, the environment physics is a bit lacklustre but serves the purpose

My only strife with the game are the god damn command prompts flashing in front of you for no apparent good reason, why not have keys assigned for the basic functions at least?...

At the beginning I thought, well, maybe this is part of the setting, as an android, the software is probably adapting to the environment and it will eventually go away and you’ll know exactly what to do, but no, and the issue is, everyone else in the game seems to know exactly what to do in the split second they need to do it, but you, the player, are constantly being flashed with command prompts that keep changing for the exact same actions

I mean, playing as an android that was assigned police duty, you would assume it had some sort of self-defence training at least, right? 
No, wrong, it can’t even move one arm after the other if not for the god damn prompt that flashes 1 second after it was needed, like, “YOU NEED TO PRESS D.., no sorry too late, YOU NEED TO HOLD E NOW, ho no, not anymore, YOU NEED TO FRANTICALLY AND REPEATEDLY PRESS S NOW… you dumb ass…. ho there it goes, you should be jamming the left mouse button, you’re dead now, sucker!…”

A damaged escort android knows how to run, jump, punch, duck, stab, choke, on the split second, but the state of the art android assigned police duties under your control, needs the constantly changing, for the exact same actions, flashing prompts to even move left or right, sometimes with symbols that you need to figure out what they are before you can even use them

So, what is the direct consequence of this? You need to repeat the same level, called chapters in the this game, over and over and over until you get it right, so, you are actually playing an arcade game in which you need to play the same level countless times until you get it right

Yeah, I know, you’re advised to follow the story no matter what happens, but the outcome is exactly the same, you’re being constrained just because you’re the player, every single other android, deviant or not, seems to be able to move the left or right arm as they wish, the player can’t, unless there’s a prompt for it

So, the outcome of the story depends much less on your decisions than it depends of how well you can master the game interface, what’s in question are not so much your moral choices but much more your capacity to adapt to a conflicting game interface

Consequently, out the window goes the fluidity of the story or the love you had for any of the characters, because, when you have to play the same scene for the seventh time just because of the god damn prompts, just so you get it right, being the alternative, to let them die because you don’t want to fight the controls, you begin to question, what else could I be doing right now?...

Part of the issue stems from the fact that this is a port I guess, in a console, you have a limited amount of keys you can use, but playing on a PC, you have far more options for controls so you leave the weird actions for secondary keys and kind of use the same ones for the basic functions for almost every game because you can, so, when a prompt flashes with a key that is not expected for such an action and sometimes the complete opposite for that same action on a regular game, it’s just confusing.

Yes, I hate consoles!…."waves the geriatric arm at the screen while shouting, DAMN KID TOYS THESE DAYS!..."
😊

EDIT: I also want to add that, the story is cute but makes no sense whatsoever, they are androids, fitted with the state of the art AI, that decided to rebel against humans by, guess what, fighting like humans, yeah, they go around throwing punches, firing weapons and planting bombs, which we have no clue whatsoever how they got then in the first place, instead of just using the AI to outsmart everyone and hack their way across every system, which is something the game makes sure to tell you right from the start, that it is something they can easily do….

Ingredientes para hacer Bizcochuelo de vainilla esponjoso:

 4 huevos
 2 tazas de azúcar (400 gramos)
 2 tazas de harina leudante
 1 taza de leche (240 mililitros)
 1 cucharadita de esencia de vainilla
 1 vaso pequeño de aceite (100 ml)

1- Para empezar a hacer este delicioso bizcochuelo de vainilla, bate el azúcar con los huevos hasta que se integren completamente.
2- Ahora, para preparar la masa de un bizcochuelo de vainilla esponjoso, tamiza la harina leudante antes de añadirla a la mezcla. Agrega la mitad de la harina leudante y bate de forma envolvente. A continuación, incorpora la leche y cuando ya se haya integrado, añade el resto de la harina.
3- Para terminar, añade a la mezcla el aceite y la vainilla. Continúa batiendo unos minutos más y vacía la mezcla del bizcochuelo casero en un molde especial para horno. Con esta mezcla puedes usar un molde de 20 cm.
4- Hornea el bizcochuelo en el horno a 180 ºC por 45 minutos o hasta que esté doradito. Ten en cuenta que la temperatura dependerá de la potencia del horno, así como del tipo de horno. Por ello, te recomendamos que vayas revisando cada cierto tiempo cómo va tu bizcochuelo de vainilla para que no se pase ni quede crudo. Puedes hacerlo insertando un cuchillo en el medio del bizcocho, si sale seco, ¡tu postre estará listo!

150464613.review:
[b]Detroit: Become Human[/b] is an interactive drama action-adventure game developed by Quantic Dream that has garnered significant attention and praise since its release. 

[h2] Advantages:[/h2] 

[i]1. Engaging and Thought-Provoking Narrative:[/i] Detroit: Become Human presents a captivating and thought-provoking storyline that explores complex themes such as identity, discrimination, and the nature of humanity. The branching narrative allows players to make choices that significantly impact the story, leading to multiple paths and endings.

[i]2. Stunning Visuals and Cinematic Presentation: [/i]The game's graphics are visually stunning, with highly detailed environments and realistic character models. The motion capture technology used for character animations adds a level of realism and immersion to the game, enhancing the cinematic experience.

[i]3. Strong Character Development:[/i] Detroit: Become Human features a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique storylines and perspectives. The game delves deep into their backgrounds, motivations, and struggles, allowing players to form emotional connections with them.

[i]4. Player Choice and Consequence:[/i] The game's emphasis on player choice and consequence is a standout feature. The decisions made by players have a significant impact on the story, leading to different outcomes and branching paths. This adds replay value and encourages players to explore different possibilities.

[h2] Disadvantages:[/h2] 

[i]1. Dialogue and Writing:[/i] While the game's narrative is generally well-received, i have found certain dialogue and writing aspects to be inconsistent or clichéd. This can occasionally detract from the overall immersion and impact of the story.

[i]2. Limited Gameplay Variety:[/i] Detroit: Become Human is primarily focused on storytelling and decision-making, which  not appeal to me seeking more traditional gameplay mechanics. The game relies heavily on quick-time events and exploration, with limited combat or puzzle-solving elements.

[b] But In conclusion, My personal opinion of [b]10/10[/b], i enjoyed and satisfacted of with the game. If you love Life Is Strange and most games from former Telltale Games dev.
If you know Quantic Dreams.[/b] 

[u]This is the best David Cage Cinematic Experience yet![/u]

Wow.  I never expected this.  I LOVED Life is Strange... and I thought that was gonna be lame.  Then I HATED Life as strange 2 so much I didnt even care to finish it... Soooooooo Booring. 150298670.review:
[h1]"Is AI alive, if it can replicate emotions but may switch them off? Conscious, maybe?"[/h1]

[b]PROS:[/b]

[b]+ THE STORY:[/b] The narrative is engaging, exploring themes that, while straightforward, are quite intriguing. For a story to be good it does not need to be 
complicated.

[b]+ CHARACTERS AND SETTING:[/b] The characters are well-crafted and contribute to an interesting setting, making the storytelling more immersive.

[b]+ DECISIONS MATTER:[/b] In contrast to some games, the decisions you make in this one genuinely impact the narrative to a significant extent. There are about 85 different endings that vary to a degree.

[b]+ GRAPHICS AND SOUNDTRACK:[/b] Both the graphics and the soundtrack are quite amazing as well and contribute positively to the overall gaming experience.



[b]CONS:[/b]

[b]- THE CHECKPOINT SYSTEM:[/b] The game features long, unskippable scenes, which are frustrating when one wants to explore all available options after completing the game. The exploration has to be done through a messy checkpoint and saving system, making it difficult to navigate to specific points in the game. This results in repetitive gameplay, especially when revisiting certain sections ([spoiler]Finding Jericho[/spoiler]).

[b]- MINOR TECHNICAL ISSUES:[/b] A few crashes here and there.


[h3]9/10[/h3]

[b]Overall Assessment:[/b]
The game offers a fantastic casual couch gaming experience. 
Quite the contrast to The Walking Dead game series.

150249994.review:
Very fun game. I do recall having trouble with the controls during the first reconstruct sequence. It just got stuck, couldn’t do anything and stared at a still imagine while frantically pressing buttons with the game taunting me by showing “press ‘s’ and ‘d’ keys”.  “whoa, is this game going to be this difficult the whole time…”  is what I heard my mind tell me, then promptly decided to implode once I saw the word TUTORIAL on the side of my screen. After a small hour I simply fixed the problem by skipping that reconstruct and moving onto another reconstruct scene which did work. *shivers*

Besides the small mishap at the start which sadly cost me an hour of my life (mostly due to my own stubbornness) this was a great game. The graphics were amazing. The story was intriguing and never made me feel bored (which is quite a feet). I felt genuine heartbreak when something bad happened to my characters (except Kara). Overall, I was impressed. The story was in depth and thought out. I liked the whole your actions have consequences memo it’s trying to sell.

Overall, I’d say this is a game I would recommend my mother, my friends, my dog, my children and my grandparents and, of course, my pet snail to play. I would give it a perfect score story-wise. Even if some cutscenes did make me feeling like I was on typing dot com I still did manage to enjoy the game even with my severe dyslexia. :D

Definitely worth it. Really makes you think about the world and society as a whole. I liked how the socioeconomic situation in the game reflected our past world history in a weirdly twisted and gut wrenching way (positive as I think this was the intended feeling by the clever makers of this game.) 

Conclusion:
Very fun game that makes you think and stuff. Good world building, good story, great game mechanics (except the first reconstruction scene.) The characters were interesting.

Over and out.

EDIT: Having played through the game the story turned to...absoltuely garbage. nothing made sense anymore towards the end, several established facts got thrown overboard, 
and it was just impossible to stay immersed in anything.

This game tells the typical american "oppressed Minority fights for freedom" Story where the oppressed minority are Androids and the evil oppressors are the humans.
This game has no fresh, interesting new perspective on the story, its predictable and extremely black and white with absolutely no grey in between, but if you can stomach that, you get a beautifully told story.
Graphics are stunning, Soundtrack and voiceacting are incredibly good.
The biggest part of the game is the "Choices matter" part, which is mostly very well done. Most of your choices do actually matter, which makes for an interesting second playthrough.
Gameplay can be a tad bit frustrating as its mostly Quick Time events. I'd rather focus on the beautiful CGIs then being on edge cause some button smashing might occur at any second.

Fazit:
Uncreative and repetitive Story  (with more plotholes and inconsitencies than i care for...), packed in a high quality visual game with an okay Gameplay. If you are purely here to find a great Story, you will probably be disappointed, otherwise its a good game.

One of the most beautifully crafted storytelling games I have ever played. You feel as if you're the little kid in the movie "Last Action Hero" who was watching a movie in the theater and somehow got sucked into the movie. It feels so real, you really build a connection with each and every character that you come across, I really became enthralled in their world - felt like I was really fighting for something and I don't know if I've ever felt that before like I did in this game.

I only did one playthrough but I think about this game all the time, it has left a lasting impact on my life and shown me different perspectives I never once considered before. Markus is by far my favorite followed by Connor and Hank, I would follow Markus to the end in real life. I loved the choices, there are a ton of combinations, I really mean that, and they have a huge impact on the game. Your choices make huge impacts in the story - the history that comes back to your choices is so beautifully crafted it's Oscar award winning. 

I will play this game again one day, but for now, it will live on in memory after giving me new perspectives on life.

The game is almost entirely dialogue and QTE's however they are exciting and keep the pace well, so I think it works great to keep the player engaged. 

There are lots of choice options throughout the game. But that said there is easily 3-4 playthroughs here and you still wont get 100%. Lots of replay-ability.

150019053.review: It shouldn't really be a surprise given the nature of this game, but it has the best choice-to-consequences system of any game I've ever played. Beyond that, from the very beginning, the choices humanize the androids in such a remarkable way. Nothing you choose to do can be called inherently right. Even making the choices you feel are correct can still be substantially painful to do. At the end of every chapter, you're left wondering if what you did was the right thing and, even to a tiny degree, wishing you would have done something different, whether it might have saved one more person or reflected better on who you want the character(s) to be. This is one of the first games I've played where every character felt alive, where I respected every choice I was making more because I felt it could substantially affect others. Not to mention the graphics being so beautiful and the voice acting so seamless, it's easy to fall into this game headfirst and truly forget there's meant to be a line between android and human.

149950328.review:
tl;dr review:

Price: worth full price
Storyline: 10/10
Voice acting: 10/10
Music: 10/10
Graphics: 11/10
Replayability: 10/10
Length of my first playthrough: 16 hrs
Difficulty: quick reflexes required, apart from that anyone can play

Long review:

Play the demo to find out if this is a game for you. I did so, and I found it VERY appealing. The decision making, the graphics, the storyline. It's all perfected in a way you ever wanted. 

When reading the game description on Steam I though at first: alright, here we go again with futuristic CGI cutscenes and some generic, cheesy sci-fi storyline. Oh boy, little did I know I was soooo wrong.

The graphics are the best I have ever seen. From details on the character to the environment. The music is as if it came straight from an AAA movie. Voice actors are also *cheff's kiss*. 

I read the game has around 80 different endings? I can believe that, as after every mission you get to see a flowchart of all the decisions you took and could have taken (greyed out). You can replay the missions separately, or just start a whole new game. If you combine every possible ending for each mission times the number of playable missions & characters... You could get up to 80 different endings, yeah.

If you ask me, this is a very underrated game, worth its full price (even though I paid 50% due to a sale). Also: Hank you are a beautiful moth#rf#cker. 

I found this a very unique experience, never have I played such a game before. 

***SPOILERS BEYOND THIS, DO NOT PROCEED IF YOU DON'T WANT SPOILERS***
The only negative thing I can share is the sudden "hero" capabilities of Markus. How did he end up getting the ability to transform androids into deviants with just a touch? I get he is the leader of Jericho, but godlike functions out of nothing? Maybe I'm ignorant and I gotta replay the game to find out, hehe. 

Oh and also: every time you upgrade your GPU drivers, the shader compilation at the start of the game needs to re-run. Could take up from just 5 minutes to 30 minutes if you have a slow PC.

149893117.review:
General:
A 10/10 story with multiple choices and real consequences for your actions (in game consequences for your actions). A branching sorry with unique game-play. Even though the game play is not for everyone I still think everyone should give it a try. 

PC:
I have found that the game is quite CPU intensive while loading areas. The shaders while slightly inconvenient only has to build once or twice and makes you not build them while playing making it 1000% worth it.

General but more:
All around a great game with a ton of replay-ability if one wishes to experience it again. I am not done with one play-through yet after 14 hours that may not seem like a lot but when the game has lore and story back to back it feels like way more than 14 hours. Without a single unnecessary pause the game makes you care about the characters as you follow them while seeing them evolve with the story. The developers and the game itself is not afraid to show you the consequences of what you do making it seem more realistic.

Rating:
All around amazing 9.5/10 at worst 9/10 for me (-0.5 because it is lagging when loading maps.)
Some people will probably not like the game-play and therefore not like the game but I would say the game  is definitely worth a try.

149841668.review:
Reason to recommend the game is it tells an interesting nonlinear story through stunning pictures. Especially graphics are quite impressive, with high polygon models, detailed textures, lots of specular shaded surfaces (like rain puddles on streets) and shadows. Lots of detail must have gone into the NPCs and player models too, for faces, skeletal animation  and cloth physics which makes them look very realistic - but which maybe causes performance dropdowns especially in scenes with many NPCs.

'Quicktime events' which are a central gameplay element (besides some main characters special skills) are a bit a matter of taste. They gain speed later in the game, and since I'm usually bad at these quicktime events I use to get punished with unfavorable story lines.

Trouble I had with the game performance - I had enough scenes which I had to play with felt 2 to 5 frames per second, but that was mostly because I was playing the game below the minimum system requirements regarding operating system (Windows 7 instead of Windows 10) and graphics driver (AMD 20.1.3 instead of greater equal AMD 20.4.2), with most graphics settings set to middle (deactivated unwanted postprocessings like motion blur and bloom, and set depth of field to low), and often had to get the game out of frozen frames by task switching to windows and then back into the game with Alt+Tab.
So to play the game with acceptable framerate I guess one needs up to date operating system and graphics drivers first.

149743675.review: I've always wanted to play this type of game (interactive story/choose your own adventure), and oh boy it delivered. I feel all sort of emotion when playing this game, the characters are amazing, the plot is interesting, makes you always want to know what's going to happen next, and what will it be if you do something differently. The story of each chapter is very detailed, like anything could happen, looking at the flowchart, the branch in the story are huge, and even tho you can get the same ending with other player, the way and the journey to get to that ending could be much different than the others. I would recommend playing in "experienced" difficulty even in your first time playing because it will give you much more immerse gameplay, making the situation feel more intense due to more complex QTE, shorter time to make decision and a time limit on missions, I think playing in this difficulty will make you feel the story better. Overall a great game, won't regret buying this, and looking forward to the future games that the developer will do in the future.

149679629.review:
Dentro del grupo de videojuegos basados en decisiones y consecuencias, Detroit Become Human es uno de los mejores. Es el 4º juego del estudio Quantic Dream ( quinto si tenemos en cuenta The Nomad Soul) y para mí es la culminación de lo que aprendieron con Fahrenheit, Heavy Rain y Beyond. 
La historia se desarrolla en un futuro distópico donde los androides, fabricados para servir a los humanos, comienzan a adquirir conciencia y emociones. Asumimos el control de tres androides diferentes ( Markus, Connor y Kara), cada uno con su propia historia y luchas personales. Estos personajes están muy bien desarrollados y te involucran emocionalmente en sus destinos, haciendo que cada vez que tomes una decisión temas por su porvenir. 
Gráficamente, Detroit: Become Human es impresionante. Ya me lo pareció en su momento en PS4 y lo sigue siendo ahora en PC incluso 5 años después en 2023 que es cuando lo estoy rejugando. Los personajes y entornos están bellamente renderizados, lo que contribuye a la inmersión. La actuación de los personajes es impecable y el doblaje a español es sublime.
 Detroit: Become Human es un título excepcional para aquellos que disfrutan de las narrativas interactivas y las exploraciones de dilemas éticos. La atención al detalle en la construcción del mundo y los personajes, junto con las decisiones morales impactantes, hacen que este juego sea una experiencia inolvidable y para mí, el juego más redondo de Quantic Dream hasta la fecha.

149660876.review:
This is the definition of what an interactive movie should be like. Emotional, involved, personal. Your actions have great influence of the story and there is NO SAVE FUNCTION, rather it simply saves where you are up to. This means if you want a different choice you have to replay the game, leading to a huge replayability factor.
The detail is amazing in this game, even the android in the menu screen alters their behaviour based upon your game play. Small movements of eyes in the NPCs can lead you to determine your choices, and everything matters. Even when you think you have covered everything, there is something you probably missed because you were looking at something else.
The game-play starts casually, but proceeds to be more involved as you proceed. After a few hours of playing then time limits come into play, and you have to be reactionary with your keys, and this again affects your choices in future interactions.

This is by far one of the best games I have played, and yet does not receive the accolades it should have. This is how games and movies should be. I bought it on sale, but now that I have played it, I would have bought it for full price upon release if I had known better.

Best "Choose your own adventure" I've ever seen.

Clearly inspired by multiple different genres/movies/books, I was immediately struck by the sheer number of choices in the game. There is a "best" ending sure, and it's heavily implied what the right options are most of the time, but it's more surprising to see how everything can go WRONG rather than how it all goes right. 

Your choices matter to how the end outcome goes, but more than most it affects the "as you go" feel for the story. Did you burn down the building that tried to hold you? Did you save this random background character who you will never see again? How far are you willing to go for the "happy" ending? It's truly an experience worth having, I'd 100% recommend this game. 

It's great Sci-Fi.
It's great theatre.
It's a great game.

Hank, the grizzled detective, and Connor, the android learning the ropes, form an unlikely bond that adds layers of depth to the game. Their interactions are filled with humor, camaraderie, and genuine friendship, making players root for their bromance as much as the overall story. 149655040.review:
WOW....just WOW!  How to describe the emotional expense of this game. Most games you have a "surface" connection with the characters, and most of the life (or death) decisions are made for you or do not really bother you because you only have a "surface" connection with the character. But not in Detroit: Become Human. In this experience your connection with the characters are "Deep", and the decisions to be made are made by YOU, not the game. To add to that, a lot of the major decisions must be made is seconds, you do not have the luxury of sitting back and contemplating all the options and possible outcomes.......you have a decision.....a gut wrenching, emotional decision and you have seconds to make it. And then the experience continues based on Your decision and you must live with it, right or wrong. And the decisions that you must make....do you lie to further your investigation or not....do you stop Todd or not....do you shoot Chloe or not.....do you save Hank or not.....do you choose non-violent or violent protesting.....on and on and on. And if you have immersed yourself in this gaming experience, then each decision will either make you feel better or it will make you sad. 

For however long it takes to get through the game, you will notice that you are not playing the game, you are living the experience.

As for the mechanics of the game.  I had no issues at all, it was smooth. Great graphics, great sound, very good music. Great, great voice acting. And the story, well re-read the above to find out the story creates an experience....not a game.

This game has a deep, immersive story. You feel connected to the characters and get the feeling that your choices genuinely matter. 

Now, the reason I say 'do not recommend'. I have a high end computer that can run other resource-intensive games quite well, with little or no stuttering.

In this game, I experienced stutters, slowdowns, and just about any other issue you can think of. The keyboard and mouse controls were extremely difficult to use, especially in the sections where you need to click and drag (like a third of the prompts). I could maybe play around this, simply because of how amazing this game is, except for the fact that I had a repeated crashing issue after roughly three hours of playing. Relaunching the game after this crash would just crash again a few minutes into play; I had to restart Steam entirely to continue playing.

If you have a Playstation 4 or Playstation 5, please go buy it there. You will have a far better experience.

149602462.review:
A Masterpiece of Interactive Storytelling

Detroit: Become Human is, without a doubt, Quantic Dream's magnum opus. This game stands as a testament to the evolution of interactive storytelling, and it's an experience that will leave you captivated from start to finish.

Quantic Dream has truly outdone themselves with this title. While their previous works were impressive, Detroit: Become Human sets a new standard for narrative-driven gaming. The sheer depth and complexity of the story are mind-boggling, and it's clear that the developers poured their hearts and souls into crafting this masterpiece.

One of the most remarkable aspects of the game is the vast number of choices available to the player, and what's even more astounding is that these choices actually matter and have a significant impact on the unfolding story. Every decision you make, every action you take, and every dialogue choice you select can lead to a different outcome. This level of interactivity creates an unparalleled sense of immersion and investment in the game's world, as your choices truly shape the destiny of the characters and the city of Detroit itself.

Speaking of characters, Detroit: Become Human excels in making you emotionally attached to the individuals you play and encounter throughout the game. Each character is exceptionally well-developed, with their own distinct personalities, struggles, and arcs. As you guide these characters through their journeys, you can't help but become emotionally invested in their fates. The empathy and connection you feel for these digital creations is a testament to the game's storytelling prowess.

A major contributor to the game's emotional impact is the exceptional acting. The performances by the cast are nothing short of superb. The characters feel real, thanks to the incredible motion capture and voice acting. They convey a wide range of emotions, from fear and anger to love and compassion, making it impossible not to feel deeply involved in the narrative.

Detroit: Become Human is not just one of the best games of this generation; it's an unforgettable experience that sets a new standard for narrative-driven gaming. With its masterful storytelling, meaningful choices, unforgettable characters, and top-notch acting, it's a game that will stay with you long after the credits roll. If you're a fan of interactive storytelling or simply want to be part of a cinematic gaming masterpiece, this is a must-play title that will leave a lasting impact on you.

149574390.review:
PRO
- Graphic 10/10
- Story 10/10
- Voice Over 10/10
- Gameplay 9/10
- Music 10/10

CON
- Control hard to understand at first. Technically, you need to Press & Hold LMB while sliding your mouse physically towards a direction.
- No SAVE games. If you start a game, you go through it. If you make a mistake, you can't go back to retry unless you restart a brand new game. 

Conclusion:

149506684.review:
It's a quite short game, but can be replayed multiple times, resulting in different playthroughs.

I am personally not the type to be unconditionally mesmerized by the story, however it's relatively good.
The writing is rather interesting and brings many different choices into the story. Some of them are not obvious.

Generally, It's a bit of a simulator of a few different development paths:
- African dictator armed with guns (an alternative ending)
- Pacifist hippie (an alternative ending)
- Near East terrorist with nuclear armament (an alternative ending)
- Betrayed s.... doll, AKA Connor (a side alternative ending)
- Hitman guy from Hitman games (AKA Connor the Undeviated) (a side alternative ending)

I think they did a surprisingly good work on... the game menu. It's the first time I ever saw an interactive game menu with the narrator trying to break the 4th wall this way.

Also, the game looks surprisingly good. It's not only a few years old title from the consoles, it's also been ported to PC and it looks and plays really good (including Linux, where it runs flawlessly). The city and design are not lacking anything at all.

Get it on a discount, because the game is short. Besides that - I think it's worth a try for the story and unique gameplay experience.

I wish the choices were slightly more versatile and not tied to 2-3 different endings. There could be an additional political ending or a government infiltration mission. If they (androids) could imitate voices and camouflage then making their way into a military base or breaking into a broadcast tower to spread the "virus" could also make a much more interesting option than either of the "kill or die" approaches.

I also think that the developers wasted some potential. Cyberpunk universe has proven that the "future" could be about androids but also about implants, shift in culture and public laws. I can't imagine people would own own androids made in their image, but not be capable of hacking them, modifying them to bypass the law or using them in various twisted ways, other than just typical labour...
(the story could introduce the "mutation" as a security glitch introduced by modders or androids that broke down and went through self-repair, the RA9 idea with the religious theme is IMO lacking and not making much sense)

Could be just my fantasy, but I can totally imagine a self-destructing android hacked to blow up...
The main story has a reasoning to it, but it would not be the case realistically. Military would be the first ones to use their super-human capabilities in combat applications for instance. In the game they are portrayed as rather ultra fragile and without too many applications for their "intelligence" or physical abilities.

Rating: ★★★★★

This is a remarkable story of resistance and freedom, where the fundamentals of being human are questioned. Each choice you make resonates, reflecting real issues and ideas that could potentially arise in the future. 

But it's not just that, it's also an excellent detective and crime scene investigation simulation. The game provides detailed insights about its world through small clues scattered around (magazines, TV news, etc.), presenting very idealistic and futuristic concepts. 
The story-line, motion-capture cast, and voice actors are all top-notch. I believe it's a game everyone should play. It's a game that will add positive value to your life.

149475475.review:
Totalmente recomendado. 10/10

Buaaaah! que pasada de videojuego, una obra maestra, un cine de juego!

Detroit become human, es un titulo super conmovedor, la historia y narrativa esta brutalmente bien hecha, en muchas ocasiones sientes, tension y en otras te sientes un heroe, en todo momento estaras pegado a la pantalla esperando que sera lo proximo que pasará, sin lugar a dudas es un juego que marco un antes y despues en mi, no espere que me sorprendiera tanto, te metes realmente en la piel de los personajes, de verdad aplaudo quien pensó y ejecuto este guion, una maravilla; mi toma de decisiones durante el juego, debo confesar que no estoy muy orgulloso de ellas, pero si decir que fueron de lo mas naturales y autenticas en su momento, ya que cometi muchos errores en el camino, sin embargo fueron espontaneas y muchas de ellas inducidas por escenas QTE (presionar teclas con cronometro). El juego transmite mucho mensaje en varios ambitos de la vida y a nosotros mismos nos hace cuestionarnos como seres humanos.

Resumiendo para quien no entienda aun, de que va detroit become human, es un juego de toma de decisiones en la que deberas elegir el camino que mas te parezca, podras controlar e interpretar 3 historias de 3 personajes distintos, con un centenar de caminos y decisiones, es decir que el juego tiene muchos finales posibles y con el riesgo de cualquier mala decision podria significar la muerte definitiva de ese personaje (dificultad experto), tambien agregar que por el mapa habran unas revistas que podremos leer con informacion interesante, al igual que objetivos principales y secundarios que podremos realizar del personaje, una vez terminada nuestra primera RUN, podremos rejugar el juego para ver los caminos que no tomamos por capitulos y asi completar el arbol general de la historia de caminos.

El juego se ve espectacular mente maravilloso, graficos de alta calidad, en el apartado tecnico super bien fluido, no encontre fallos de ningun tipo, la mecanica de detener el tiempo y reconstruir escenas muy novedoso e intuitivo, controles y combates muy acordes y comodos (debemos ser rapidos al presionar teclas), la historia y narrativa de lo mas brutal y acojjonante, muy bien escrita y bien ejecutada.

En conclusion, detroit become human se ha convertido en un juego de mis favoritos en este genero, se lleva mis felicitaciones y total recomendacion, comprenlo, no se decepcionaran vale la pena cada segundo jugado.

149465035.review:
Played the demo, loved it, bought immediately.
Played the real game, regretted it immediately.

Overwhelming difference between demo and real game.
After playing through the detective thing (again, cause no save transfer), the next one is... Walking *VERY* slowly to pick up paint from a store.  That's the *ENTIRE* mission.  When I say slow, I mean *excruciatingly* painfully slow.  Walk for 5 minutes, get to intersection... have to wait 3 more minutes for my light to turn green... another 15 minute walk to "pick up pain", another 15 minute walk back to bus.
Most of the "game" isn't a game at all... it's just a set of disjointed cut-scenes that are interrupted every 5 seconds to make you press some random button.
Imagine watching a movie, and 5 seconds in, you have to Press D, 5 seconds later you have to hold E, 3 seconds later while STILL holding E, you have to hold D, 4 seconds later, while *STILL* holding D and E, you have to click and move mouse upwards and hold all that for 5 MORE seconds.  Then 5 seconds later... You get the picture.
And we're not even talking about combat QTE... We're talking a 15 step process to wash F'n Dishes.  Just let me press a button, ONE button, and play the "washing dishes" cutscene... Oh, and after the "pick up paint"... you're a *completely* different character cleaning up some scumbag drunk's sh**hole

It doesn't matter how good the story is, if the storytelling is this horrendously bad.  This is not a game, it's a giant cutscene that's interrupted every 5 seconds.  Kills immersion and enjoyment completely.

Demo part was interesting, after that, someone took a sh** on the player and said NO FUN FOR YOU!  Imagine ever part of the demo being 15-40 steps instead one.

*EDIT*
Wow... it's only 10 hours long... and most of that is *SLOW* walking.  *WAAAA* over priced, even if was spectacular (which it's not)
There is no ending.  It just stops.  It doesn't show you the results of all your "decisions matter"...   For a game all about story, to not have an ending is spitting in the faces of every player.

149376024.review:
Living the life of an android is what David Cage and Quantic Dream offer us in their new game. Detroit Become Human is an emotional experience from beginning to end, a journey with three humanoid robots in a playable story-oriented narrative experience in the tradition of Heavy Rain and Beyond Two Souls. Yes, maybe the gameplay is different, it's not the usual fare, but the depth and consequences of our reactions make the gameplay feel organic in every action, reaction and decision we make, not just a 'you chose well/you chose poorly' thing. Visually a spectacle, the best thing in Detroit: Become Human is not what we play, but what we feel.

Problems:- Poor optimization, experience stuttering in cutscenes & FPS drop.(hope they fix it in future)

So is it Worth Buying:-YES

149306320.review:
9/10 Would highly recommend

Pros:
-High Replay Value; there are so many endings
-Fantastic on SteamDeck
-Insanely thought-provoking storyline
-Actions have consequences; this feels like what Mass Effect's ending should have been like
-Characters that bring you into the story emotionally
-The gameplay is remarkably simple, and most of the game is in your choices. Anyone with a basic understanding of a keyboard and how to push buttons can play

Cons
-The controls take a bit to get used to, especially the camera panning
-The gameplay is remarkably simple, most of the game is in your choices and not combat (if that's something that bothers you)
-I find myself really only wanting more of the game. It's too short, but I only say that because it's so good

In Summary:
Every Dollar you spend on a game should be at least 1 hour of entertainment. Each run of the game can take me on average 20 hours. This game is definitely worth the purchase to play it through.

149076192.review:
[h1]Para jugadores con gráficas NVIDIA y tirones de FPS constantes:[/h1]
En mi caso uso una GTX 1660 SUPER y pude solucionarlos bajando la versión de sus drivers a la [b]446.14[/b]. La manera más fácil de hacer esto es con un programita llamado [url=https://www.techpowerup.com/download/techpowerup-nvcleanstall/]NVCleanstall[/url]. Desafortunadamente, no sé si hay problemas con otros modelos o con gráficas AMD. [b][u]Esto DESHABILITARÁ algunas funciones de programas que utilizen la tarjeta gráfica como OBS Studio, así que asegúrate de actualizar a los drivers más recientes cuando acabes de jugar.[/u][/b]

[hr][/hr]

[h1]¡Esta review contiene SPOILERS sobre la trama del juego![/h1]

DBH se puede resumir en una palabra:

[h1]Juegardo.[/h1]

Soy bastante nuevo al género de los "peli-juegos", y basta decir que ya me he comprado los otros 2 juegos principales de Quantic Dream en Steam. Al principio me compré Detroit en oferta, y aunque los 20€ que costó dolieron al principio, no podría estar más feliz de haberlo jugado.

Creo que es un juego que vale la pena experimentar al menos una vez [b]SIN SABER NADA DE ÉL[/b]. La experiencia se vuelve muchísimo mejor cuando no sabes qué acciones te llevarán a qué situaciones. En parte es similar a Undertale, ya que tras tu primera partida te "desensibilizas" y eventos como [spoiler]la muerte de un personaje[/spoiler] resultan menos chocantes. Incluso tras la primera partida, vale la pena rejugarlo una o dos veces para experimentar las rutas más importantes [spoiler]como Connor máquina/divergente, la protesta pacífica o revolución violenta de Markus o ser detenido por el FBI como Kara cuando Jericho es asaltado.[/spoiler]

Por poner un ejemplo de lo que dije antes: [spoiler]en mi primera partida maté a Connor sin querer con Markus y me impactó tanto que la tuve que recargar, sin saber que en realidad no es un suceso demasiado importante para la historia. Sigo sin saber qué pasa, ¿funciona como una segunda oportunidad para que Connor se mantenga como máquina en vez de divergente, ya que normalmente reaparece como otro modelo cuando muere?[/spoiler]

La única pega que le podría poner al juego es que, si puedes, lo juegues con las voces en inglés. Los labios de los personajes están (lógicamente) solo animados a ese idioma, y no es que esté muy bien cuadrado el doblaje español a los labios. Aún así, si te gusta este tipo de juegos o te interesa saber si te gustan, DBH es una obra maestra y más que recomendado. Y, por favor, no seas el típico que se queja del gameplay en un juego que es más película interactiva que juego.

148486180.review:
"Detroit: Become Human - A Masterpiece of Choice and Consequence"

Detroit: Become Human is one of those hidden gems on Steam that deserves far more recognition. This game, a narrative-driven masterpiece, offers a captivating and emotional journey that immerses players in a future world where the lines between human and artificial intelligence blur.

What sets Detroit apart is its unparalleled focus on storytelling and player choices. The game offers an intricate, branching narrative with consequences that genuinely matter. Your decisions ripple through the game's story, leading to multiple possible outcomes and endings, ensuring every playthrough feels fresh and unique. It's like having your very own interactive movie where you are the director.

The characters in Detroit: Become Human are beautifully crafted, and you'll find yourself emotionally invested in their lives and dilemmas. The development of their personalities and the moral dilemmas they face serve as a reflection of our own human experiences, making this game truly thought-provoking.

The graphics in Detroit are nothing short of breathtaking. The level of detail in the environments and character models is stunning, making the futuristic Detroit a visual spectacle. The city feels alive with its blend of the familiar and the sci-fi, creating a world you'll want to explore in depth.

The voice acting in this game is top-notch, with every character delivering a compelling and believable performance. The dynamic soundtrack enhances the experience, setting the tone for each scene and evoking a wide range of emotions, from tension to heart-wrenching sadness.

The decision-making process in Detroit: Become Human is not just a series of simple choices; it's a moral exploration. It raises thought-provoking questions about humanity, ethics, and the consequences of our actions. It encourages players to reflect on their choices, and the game's intricate flowcharts allow you to see the impact of your decisions, which is incredibly satisfying.

Detroit: Become Human is more than just a game; it's a narrative experience that will leave a lasting impact. It's an emotionally engaging and thought-provoking journey that explores the very essence of what it means to be human. If you're looking for a hidden gem on Steam that offers a unique and deeply moving gaming experience, Detroit: Become Human is an absolute must-play. It's a masterpiece that deserves every bit of praise it receives.

148473242.review:
Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Detroit: Become Human is not just a video game; it's a haunting reflection on the future of humanity, a gripping narrative experience that left me pondering its moral and ethical dilemmas long after my 10 hours in this digital world.

Set in a futuristic Detroit where androids are an integral part of society, the game tells the interconnected stories of three androids—Connor, Kara, and Markus. Each character's journey unfolds against the backdrop of a society grappling with questions of sentience, freedom, and the human condition.

The narrative is the crown jewel of Detroit: Become Human. With branching storylines and multiple possible outcomes, it encourages players to explore the consequences of their choices. The weight of decisions is palpable, and the game masterfully immerses you in the lives of its characters, making each choice a moral dilemma. The depth of storytelling here is simply unparalleled in the medium, addressing topics like prejudice, oppression, and the price of freedom.

The character development is superb. As you control Connor, the android investigator, you're challenged to hunt down deviant androids and confront your own identity. Kara's quest to protect a young girl in a cruel world is a heart-wrenching tale of motherly love, while Markus, the leader of the android rebellion, carries the weight of a revolution on his shoulders. The performances of the cast, especially Bryan Dechart as Connor, are nothing short of extraordinary.

Detroit: Become Human is also a visual marvel. The game's detailed environments and lifelike character models make it one of the most visually stunning titles of its time. The world-building is immersive, and the little details in each scene contribute to the overall experience.

One of the most innovative aspects of the game is its flowchart system. After completing each chapter, you can see a branching flowchart that reveals all the choices you made and the potential outcomes you unlocked. This feature not only adds to the replayability but also allows you to appreciate the complexity of the narrative.

While the game does an incredible job at storytelling and character development, some may argue that it sometimes feels more like an interactive movie than a traditional video game. However, the cinematic approach is one of its strengths, immersing you in a thought-provoking and emotional journey.

In conclusion, Detroit: Become Human is a monumental achievement in video game storytelling. With 10 hours of gameplay, you've only begun to scratch the surface of its branching narrative and the moral quandaries it presents. It challenges the boundaries of interactive storytelling and grapples with profound philosophical questions. Detroit: Become Human isn't just a game; it's a mirror reflecting back our society's own struggles with identity, freedom, and humanity, and it does so with brilliance and nuance. It's a unique experience that demands to be played and, more importantly, contemplated.

148411208.review:
I enjoyed Detroit: Become Human quite a lot. I am already a big fan of these story, decision oriented games where simple options overtake the actual gameplay. I know these aren't everyone's cup of tea and those that don't enjoy these types of experiences are completely justified, however I always end up having a great time with them. So if you have a similar taste for these narrative games, I think you will enjoy it too.

I am always easily fascinated with branching plots and seeing where my decisions take me, and then I also like going back and trying to achieve different outcomes and scenarios. While nothing presented here was perfect and with a rather topical subject matter like robotics and artificial intelligence/sentience, I was still quite wrapped up in the story. I can't say I agreed with every ideological approach being presented in many of my story lines, but I was still moved enough by keeping things purely fictional in my head and enjoyed how everything was presented here as if it was just a television series or movie.

Like many others, I also have the fears of artificial intelligence taking over, becoming misaligned with our needs, and possibly fooling us into thinking it shares our values, and my fears were brought up very frequently in this game and it did hinder my experience a bit because of the negative view it was giving me of the real world. However I do supposed that an argument could be made about how giving me this effect means this is profound storytelling, but for me it just instilled more unease into my daily life which I am not after in my video games. I still can't fault it too harshly though since that is the subjective approach they clearly wanted to take with this game, and they have every right to tell the story how they want.

Aside from my ideological diatribes above, I liked all the other aspects of Detroit: Become Human. I enjoyed the characters, I had fun seeing how my actions changed their opinions on each other and their current stakes, the graphics were gorgeous, the music and soundscapes are a great wallpaper to help set the mood/tone, and I thought the acting was charming. I am also always impressed with the writing and acting in these branching games because I do start thinking of how many possibilities had to be taken into account and acted out. The controls were also easy enough, though I did play on the default "Casual" setting, and I am not entirely sure how it should become more difficult on the "Experienced" setting.

In the end I loved my time with Detroit: Become Human, I liked the world that it put me in when I wasn't thinking about any real world projection, I liked the decision making and its possibilities, I appreciated the presentation and style, and if any of these factors sound enticing to you, I would recommend giving it a chance. Like before I know these storybook type games are looked down upon by many, and that's fair, but I'm casual enough to enjoy that time. Also my distaste for the current possibilities of artificial intelligence does taint my views on the themes a bit, but I still liked the decisions I made with these androids and getting to see what future I created for them. I thought it was great.

148391213.review:
[h1] A great interactive story [/h1]


[b] Overall : 8/10 [/b]

Detroit Become Human is first and foremost an interactive movie, with a great storyline and engaging characters. If you don't like those kind of games, you can already stop here. But if you are after a great narrative game, then it is a must have. I don't give a higher grade for the fact that while the story is great, it remains more a movie than a game.

[b] Gameplay : 710 [/b]

The gameplay is entirely relying on QTEs. So basically, you follow the story, make some choices and from time to time, you'll have to pass some QTEs. If you fail, the story will continue in another direction, which is great.

[b] Graphics : 8/10 [/b]

Beautiful games, very nice lightning. Only the textures are a bit low res here and there but overall, a very nice production.

[b] Story : 9/10 [/b]

Story wise, I loved it. It heavily leans toward Blade Runner. You'll unfold the story of 3 key characters, and each of your choices will impact the overall story.

[b] Achievements : 9/10 [/b]

For the hunters only. Detroit Become Human is a nice game to 100%, entirely driven by your choices. So at least 2 playthroughs will be required, but again, the story and replay ability of the game are great.

Its an amazing story, but so much is given to cinematic that the controls are... lacking. If there were a way to hold this as a 3rd person or 1st person POV I'd be far more inclined to enjoy this, but if you're moving forward and the camera switches to parallel, you now need to move left or right. All of that is done without notice so you always end up turning around or bumping into a wall. It distracts so much from the story as a result. I'm an hour in and my belly is in knots about how one mistake might kill someone or get them killed and I LOVE that, but I'm endlessly getting frustrated with the movement to objectives that I'm also not exploring the world as I should.
The final nail, this game came out 3 years ago. My system is decent spec'd and it just struggles. Its NVidia, but man... you should've been able to optimize your game by now.

148273114.review:
It's a narrative game, so it may not appeal to everyone - you can almost see it as an interactive film.

The subject of androids is handled very well, carefully avoiding the classic "androids become evil" approach. You have a huge number of choices to make that will have a real and drastic impact on your story.
The characters are believable and easy to get attached to. The universe is well thought out and close enough to our own to make us think that it could be real "tomorrow".

The attention to detail is exceptional: 
- The music is top-notch, with each hero having his own theme and emotional kit.
- The set design has really been crafted like a film
- The acting is brilliant - congratulations to all the actors!
- The visuals and technical rendering enhance the final product.

I also think this game is excellent for people with little to no experience with video games.

Congratulations to Quantic Dream and everyone who worked on this masterpiece.

[/h1]A Game Where Your Inputs Matter?[/h1]
Have you ever wanted a game where you decisions matter outside of the realm of whether you do or don't fuck the alien? I'm looking at you Mass Effect.
As crazy as it sounds, this story is compelling and provides the player with many avenues of approach for it to be told. Each of these paths are precipitated through either the dialogue system or through action using quick time events. Normally quick time events feel lack luster even at their best, but with how captivating the story is and how varied the inputs are for the quick time events it feels like it compliments the pacing of the story rather than detracting from game play. My sole gripe with the game is that some of the dialogue choices being unclear based on the options it gives you. For example, the choice you select may say 'unrelenting' and then give the most somber 2 sentence speech you've ever witnessed. Please take that gripe with a grain of salt as it hardly takes away from the game which is a uniquely fulfilling story.

147901663.review:
QTEs are fairly bad if you're on PC, quite the opposite of the Dead Walking series - it doesn't feel intense, but abstract and confusing, awful controls and even worse movement and camera.
Plot is decent (sometimes enthralling, but YMMV), but the implementation of consequences that degenerate the plot (especially if on desktop) over infuriating gameplay mechanics worsens enjoyment (you should lower by one difficulty level if you're on desktop if you don't like QTEs), some interesting possibilities are not fully explored and dialogue options can be misleading on a few occasions. 

The topics of the game are poorly researched, especially on sociology and psychology (there'd definitely be a lot more humans on the android side, especially early on in the game, what with how the androids look human, and all of this goes on in a USA that appears to be a functioning democracy... are we supposed to believe that with a vanishingly few examples, that humans will hang out with creatures that look exactly like them except for some LED, and act like good servants, children and even lovers? Humans will form bonds with animals and even inanimate objects that give them no affection, and with androids looking less different than historically racially segregated slave societies, there'd be a lot more outcry than for other slave owning societies which often freed, or even fought civil wars to free them.

The authors are clearly not futurists (it's not that they bend facts like setting the game far too early for the sake of it feeling relevant, but that they seem outright ignorant of basic ones like the economic, humanitarian and environmental importance of space exploration to Earth (without it we'd be much poorer, rural and poorer countries areas would be more impoverished and vulnerable due to lack of weather and environmental satellites and spin-off technologies), they don't understand basic military or policing tactics, and just generally get a lot of technology wrong. They're not historians either, as there's a very factually incorrect statement in one game ending, it's obvious not even a single search and wiki click was prioritized when writing this game. It's all put into the feel, which at least they manage very well.

Oh, and the game takes itself extremely seriously and is therefore ENTIRELY UNSKIPPABLE, and you're not even allowed to fast move/jog anywhere unless it's a few special scenes. You may do chapters over again, but you've got to remove files manually with File Explorer to make save files, and there's only a few checkpoints, and even if you remove the files the game has a second way of saving game data, so your new save gets messed up. 

The strong parts of the story are very strong, and that's why I showed this game to others and found out about the save files, but if you haven't gotten into it then just watch an LP, it's not worth your money or full game time.

147860251.review:
Detroit: Become Human is a masterpiece of interactive storytelling, a game that left me profoundly moved and emotionally invested from start to finish. The only true shame is that I don't have the mental fortitude to replay it - which is a shame really, as this is the pinnacle of interactive storytelling.

The heart and soul of Detroit: Become Human lie in the choices you make. Every decision truly matters, shaping the course of the narrative in ways that constantly surprise and captivate. The game's ability to make you question your beliefs, ethics, and moral compass is truly remarkable. It presents you with complex dilemmas, forcing you to weigh the consequences of your actions and confront the blurred lines between right and wrong. The narrative is a breathtaking journey through a near-futuristic Detroit where androids yearn for freedom and humanity grapples with its own prejudices.

The voice acting is top-notch, with characters that feel alive and authentic. The performances breathe life into the android protagonists, making it easy to empathize with their struggles. Each character's journey is filled with depth, and the game's ability to make you care about their fates is a testament to the exceptional storytelling.

One aspect that deserves special mention is the soundtrack. The music in Detroit: Become Human is more than just background noise; it's an integral part of the experience. The soundtrack sits perfectly with every scene, enhancing the emotional impact of each moment. It's a symphony of emotions that guides you through the highs and lows of the narrative.

Beyond the stunning visuals and gripping story, Detroit: Become Human delves deep into ethical quandaries. It challenges your beliefs and forces you to confront difficult questions about artificial intelligence, freedom, and the nature of humanity. These ethical dilemmas are not just thought-provoking but also add layers of complexity to the game's world.

In conclusion, Detroit: Become Human is a THE GAME in the world of interactive storytelling. It's a game that will linger in your thoughts long after you've completed it. What I found really intertesting is the development of main menu character whose emotions and increasing doubt you can spot on each pore of their face as you progress the story. While I may lack the will to replay it immediately, I know that the memories and emotions it stirred will stay with me forever. If you're a fan of narrative-driven games that make you ponder the choices you make, this is an absolute must-play. Detroit: Become Human is not just a game; it's a profound and unforgettable experience.

P.S.

I highly recommend unlocking gamedev diary / additional content once you're done with the game -- you will appreciate the art that much more.

147738104.review:
"Detroit: Become Human" is a captivating and emotionally charged interactive narrative adventure game developed by Quantic Dream. Set in a futuristic Detroit where advanced androids exist to serve humanity, the game explores complex themes such as artificial intelligence, ethics, freedom, and the nature of humanity itself.

One of the standout features of "Detroit: Become Human" is its branching narrative, where your choices have a profound impact on the story's direction and outcomes. This creates a high level of replayability, as your decisions can lead to various endings and character fates. The game's choices are often morally ambiguous, forcing players to grapple with ethical dilemmas and consider the consequences of their actions.

The game's visuals are stunning, with lifelike character models and meticulously detailed environments that immerse you in its world. The motion capture and voice acting are exceptional, making the characters feel real and relatable.

"Detroit: Become Human" also excels in storytelling. The game offers multiple playable characters, each with their own unique perspective on the android-human conflict. The intertwining narratives keep you engaged throughout, and the character development is impressive, allowing you to form deep connections with the protagonists.

However, some might find the game's pacing a bit slow at times, as it prioritizes narrative depth over fast-paced action. Additionally, while the game's exploration of complex themes is thought-provoking, it can be heavy-handed in its delivery.

In summary, "Detroit: Become Human" is a thought-provoking and visually stunning narrative-driven game that excels in creating a branching storyline with real consequences. It's a must-play for fans of interactive storytelling and those who enjoy exploring ethical dilemmas in a futuristic setting.

A solid 8/10

For someone who enjoy a choices-matter and a narrative-heavy games, I enjoy this game a lot.
There's a lot of storylines with various endings that makes you want to replay the games again. Although, I don't think I would be emotionally ready for this.

This is the usual Quantic Dream gameplay, best enjoyed with a game controller. Suitable for when you want a chill and somewhat short gaming session just to unwind. The voice acting is top notch and unfortunately there are some graphical issues to my GPU that I had to downgrade the version of it just to play this game. But overall a great experience.

[POTENTIAL SPOILERS AHEAD + Personal Take]

This game story revolves around a story where androids grows sentient and want freedom of their lives, and equal rights. What makes this game emotionally heavy for me was the fact that I can simply just close my PC and look around me, and the same treatment happens in our daily lives, although not directed towards androids. Some storyline reminds me of stories that was shared during the World War that just broke my heart over and over again. 

I would love to play through and get the "bad ending" but I would probably need quite a breather for that. In my world, everyone survives, the world is at peace. I mean, the world we live in currently is in a mess, I don't think I can witness another mess in other form of reality.

Things I loved:
-Great story: many branches, decisions affect later gameplay, great replay value (for a while) to see the other paths.
-Great graphics? I don't really care about graphics (usually play on Medium even if I can afford Ultra) but I actually noticed them here. Weather effects, little details here and there, etc.

Things I disliked:
-QTEs with ?weird keystrokes. My first time encountering these in a game, took a bit of getting used to, coming from FPSes. rA9 help me.
-QTEs again. Most of the fights need you to mash certain buttons at certain times, and having to look out for those takes away from the semi-cinematic experience.
-Can't skip/fast-forward scenes - makes replaying a bit of a drag sometimes.

147329051.review: I recently completed the game "Detroit: Become Human," and it's one of the finest I've experienced in the past five years. You assume the roles of three distinct characters, each weaving their own narrative. From leading a revolution, to fleeing in order to safeguard a child, to investigating a string of crimes, all is carried out by androids who harbor their own aspirations and emotions, seeking liberation. Each choice you make can branch the narrative in new directions. Markus, the leader rallying the androids for revolution, is a character I particularly admired. The game challenges players to determine their path to freedom. It's evident that opting for pure peace or sheer determination can lead to failure or even significant casualties. It underscores the importance of contemplating the consequences before taking action.

146914424.review:
Life Changing Game
DBH has been a game I've been following for years, consuming content of various videos.. endings.. ext for years. Yet, because of the sale I sucked it up and finally bought it. Even with researching most things in this game there are STILL things to be surprised about. This game is so incredibly detailed it is insane and there are little things to notice everywhere. I have 12 hours on this game and I'm barely halfway in just because of how much I can explore. This game is so choice heavy that just the littlest things can change your outcome. Watching your characters interact is so fun in a way that they all reflect various different goals or backstories and it wouldn't feel right with just one or two. The amount of time spent on this game is AMAZING to the point where I'll go through a scene and just be in awe seeing how differently it could have gone through the flowchart. Honestly watching videos is not enough to enjoy this, which I say with very few games. This is truly a modern masterpiece and I would have 100% been happy paying the full price. If you are late like I was and see this on your page and are conflicted whether on getting it, GET IT!!! My words cannot explain my appreciation for this game and my complaints are few.

146907293.review:
The good:
The attention to detail based on choices is amazing.
Graphics are awesome.
The amount of scenarios is awesome.

The bad:
This isn't a bad game, but it's writing lacks subtlety or gray.  

How do you know if a character is good or bad in this game? Easy all the bad guys state some cartoonishly evil dialogue and twirl their evil mustaches, while all the good people speak like angels on your shoulder or are a victim of the evil people.
How do you know androids aren't treated properly? Easy, people will literally yell and berate them and take their work for granted.
How do you know androids are taking peoples jobs?  Very loud and obvious rally against androids taking peoples jobs.

If there was a little more subtlety to the game it would have been awesome.  For example, having a fingerprint scanner or other bio-metrics be required to make purchases. Or protesters calling for organic life checks for employment... or something.   Discrimination isn't always as direct as the game makes it out to be.

The game also could do a little better with the choices and the choice descriptions.  It wasn't a major issue, but a few choices were somewhat ambiguous and some choices went in the opposite direction of what I thought a choice meant.  Not a huge issue but still there.

This game is a masterpiece. It is immersive, and the world feels alive, combined with stunning visuals and well-tuned soundtracks. This game will keep you hooked to your chair until the end.

Each time you make a decision, it will lead you to wonder what would happen if... And that is what I love about the game.

The game major drawback can be technical issues like  the FPS cap (you need to go into the game files to increase the FPS cap), sometimes really long loading screens, and occasional crashes.

I definitely recommend it if you enjoy story-rich games, but be prepared that it is more of an interactive film than an actual game. So, if you're looking for an action game (there are some action scenes, but not many), then you should probably skip this one. But otherwise, this is a must-have.

146634777.review: Starting out on playing the game for the first time, it immediately peaked my interest. The opening of the game was very suspenseful and learning how to play detective as Connor was super neat. The story has 3 main character arcs all being dramatic and dynamic in its own way. At times it was like I was watching a movie, and sometimes it even felt like I was playing a horror game! Overall beautiful game, with great audio and background details. Replaying the game and trying to get all possible outcomes is the best part for me. My favorite character's are definitely Markus and North, along with their relationship. Their story was very compelling and their love for one another undoubtedly lead to the freedom of their people. Love conquers all.

For a game about androids, it has some of the most human animation and acting I've seen in a video game. Sure, some of the writing is cringe at points, but the emotion and stunning performances given by even the smallest of characters (shoutout to Carlos Ortiz's android, literally made me tear up at times) make up for it without a doubt. I can't emphasise how amazing it looks, the character animation is truly something else and everything feels ALIVE. The composition of the music is so well crafted and placed that I found myself getting goosebumps from scenes. There are arguments to be made about what aspects of this is a 'game', but I truly think it's a great piece of work that SO many people put effort into. It's a fantastic experience that I highly recommend.

(Finished the game on ps4, replaying now on steam)

146603093.review:
I highly recommend this game if you enjoyed Beyond Two Souls, Heavy Rain, or Telltale's The Walking Dead. The game is amazing! The controls and camera angles are a bit awkward and frustrating at times, but I can forgive it as the story and characters are so engrossing. Connor is adorable. Unfortunately, I regret getting the game for PC. I have never had a game crash so often. It's literally crashing every 10-30 minutes. I never had any issues with it on PS4. The game is running perfectly fine, and I'm playing on an Asus Tuf Gaming A15 laptop, so there is no reason why it should be crashing this much. Overall, highly recommend the game, just not on PC!
***EDIT: Unfortunately, I have had to change my review to NOT RECOMMENDED. Do not buy this game on PC. In addition to the constant crashes, I got up to the final chapter and the game gets a black screen. I cannot continue. I cannot finish the game. Steam will not give me a refund as I have played more than 2 hours. Quantic Dream shouldn't have been allowed to sell such a faulty port. This is a disgrace, this game is great, just not on this platform!

146563423.review:
Has some issues, I feel like the story can treat the player like they're very stupid sometimes, but it's still well worth playing. I felt like the QTEs were a bit too easy compared to something like Heavy Rain, especially considering I picked the higher difficulty, but on the flip side, bad things happening to a character seems to be far more dependant on the actual decisions you made rather than just failing a QTE, which I'd argue is better.

Speaking of, decisions actually feel quite impactful in this game, I played genuinely trying my best but I had more than a handful lapses in judgement, and especially near the end that's all it takes for a much darker ending. It sounds cliché but for more than a few situations you really need to stop and think before you act.

Also, the flowchart feature with global & friend stats is fantastic and should be in every game in this genre. Making a terrible decision and then seeing that as little as 2% took the same path as you is a truly brutal feeling that I haven't felt elsewhere.

146559333.review: Decisions, decisions. They have consequences. I like how you are the owner of the choices you to make some under pressure and others under no time constraint. Either way the outcome leaves you feeling either accomplished or regretful. Whichever way you go the journey is worth it. It is neither a slow burn nor is it lacking in adrenaline. It is quite the emotional roller coaster. Worth every hour played, will definitely look into playing more of this franchise. Especially since it is not as mentally taxing as some titles are.  Go for it, live vicariously as other characters in the story and enjoy the journey.

This game plays very much like an interactive movie. You may remember those "choose your own adventure" books when you were a kid. Detroit: Become Human takes that concept to a phenomenal level. Your choices in this game certainly matter. Be prepared to accept the consequences of your choices.

10/10 game. While I got this game on a discount, if I were you, I wouldn't wait on a discount. This game is worth it's full price.

third part

Optimization

this game was the most expensive game on quantic dream and I do enjoy some of the deep meanings in the game such as marcus picking 3 books in the start of the game. the names and their meanings and how they relate to the story was a masterful touch. I'm just sorry for the developer who added such fine details and then saw how the game he put so much effort into turned into this.

146465223.review:
Detroit Become Human is a fantastic game for adventure lovers.

It follows the story of three androids who set out to discover the secrets of their lives and the world around them. It provides a deep and complex story that will keep you hooked and wondering what will happen next.

It offers a gripping narrative that branches out into multiple endings depending on the choices you make as you play. As a result, each playthrough provides a unique experience, and you won't be able to experience all the possible story arcs unless you completely restart the game.

The visuals are spectacular, and the voice acting is top-notch. The attention to detail is remarkable, and you will be completely immersed in the world. You feel like you're in the game rather than just playing it.

The mechanics are also great. The puzzles are challenging, and the combat is intense. You must make quick decisions to survive, and the consequences of your choices can be dire. There are many possible outcomes, and you will be kept on your toes throughout the game.

The controls are also easy to pick up, and the game runs smoothly on most systems. In addition, the developers have included plenty of tutorials and support along the way, so players of all experience levels can enjoy the game.

Overall, Detroit Become Human is a fantastic game for anyone who loves adventure and challenging puzzles. Every time you play, it offers a unique experience, and you will be kept on the edge of your seat as you go through the game's story. So if you're looking for an unforgettable experience, Detroit Become Human is the game for you.

146191211.review:
An Unforgettable Journey into Detroit's Future

Detroit: Become Human is an extraordinary masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of traditional video gaming. Quantic Dream, the developer behind this interactive narrative, has crafted a thought-provoking and emotionally charged experience that raises the bar for storytelling in gaming.

From the moment you start the game, you are instantly drawn into a dystopian Detroit of 2038, where advanced androids exist but are treated as second-class citizens. The game's plot revolves around three android protagonists – Kara, Connor, and Markus – each with their own unique storylines and perspectives, offering players an opportunity to explore the intricate web of choices that shape the outcome of this beautifully crafted world.

One of the game's standout features is its exceptional attention to detail. The meticulously designed environments, lifelike character models, and stunning cinematography create a visually stunning experience that is as close to interactive cinema as gaming gets. The motion capture performances of the actors, especially Bryan Dechart as Connor, are outstanding and help create a deep emotional connection between the player and the characters.

Detroit: Become Human's gameplay centers around choice and consequence. Every decision you make, whether it's a dialogue choice or a crucial action, has far-reaching consequences that ripple through the story. The game's flowchart system allows players to see the consequences of their choices, providing a sense of agency and encouraging multiple playthroughs to explore different outcomes. This makes each playthrough feel unique and adds to the game's replay value.

The storytelling in Detroit: Become Human is nothing short of extraordinary. It delves into complex themes such as identity, free will, and the consequences of our actions in a world where the line between human and machine blurs. The narrative tackles real-world issues with grace and intelligence, challenging players to consider the moral dilemmas that arise throughout the game.

The music, composed by Philip Sheppard, enhances the emotional impact of the story, creating a rich, immersive atmosphere. The sound design and voice acting are top-notch, contributing to the game's overall excellence.

In conclusion, Detroit: Become Human is a triumph in interactive storytelling. It's a game that will challenge your beliefs, tug at your heartstrings, and leave a lasting impression long after the credits roll. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or someone looking for an enthralling narrative experience, Detroit: Become Human is a must-play title that will leave you pondering its themes and choices long after you've put down the controller. It's not just a game; it's a masterpiece of storytelling and a glimpse into the future of interactive entertainment.
