146124227.review:
Incredible graphic design that's still trending in 2023. I adore how the narrative shifts based on the audience and how the stories initiate from different perspectives only to converge cohesively in the end. When I, a human, play the android, it's fascinating how the finale unfolds.

The bond between Connor and Hank, the familial ties of Alice, Kara, and Luther, and the love between Markus and North all underscore the evolution of android consciousness. These relationships culminate in a clarion call for equality and rights.

Deducting 0.1 for not reuniting Alice, Kara, and Luther. The ending could have been a tad more idealistic, especially since android tech remains tethered to humanity (smells like a potential counterattack?). Still, it's a stellar game that prompts deep reflection on the dynamics between humans and androids. <3

146089935.review: Detroit: Become Human is more of an interactive movie than something you sit down and play. It is a dystopian choose your own adventure game where your choices are powerful and affect the game world as well as the narrative. The story is fantastic and the main characters are done very well, each one is compelling in their own right, although some are definitely more interesting than others. The graphics are very good, aided by strong cinematography and an uplifting score. It must be said that this game features a lot of QTE (quick time events) which will definitely put some people off, however, if you enjoy story rich games then you can probably overlook these as the narrative is well worth experiencing. The main story is around 10 hours but you can spend a lot longer discovering alternate choices and endings - I think most people will agree that the game merits more than a single playthough. Unfortunately I have personally experienced 4 random crashes so far but this hasn't soured my opinion on the game. I'd rate Detroit: Become Human a solid 8/10. It's not for everyone and it's not flawless, but it certainly reaches some high highs and I enjoyed my time thoroughly.

Detroit Become Human, what a beutiful and well optimized game this is, playing this game for the first time will actually shock you by how well optimized and polished this game is. I mean yeah sure, this game was a playstation exclusive once upon a time but has now made it's way to pc which i love. I have watched so many youtubers play this game and maybe a lot of people will say "well you are spoiling yourself, good job!" this is not the case with this game, the possibilities and endings in this game are not just generic "oh here is your new ending cutscene like dying light 2" this game is just more than that, the endings are pretty much endless as long as you get all of them ofc.

Story: The story is probably one of it's main selling points, it's a story set in 2038 where humans have created such things called Androids or robots if you will, but then one day something snaps inside of them and they want to change and stop being endless slaves for the humankind.

Characters: Connor is one the three main characters in this story who's part in the story is to find the leader of an illegal organization of who'm the Androids created and meanwhile deal with the worlds kindest nd most broken lieutenant there is to clear police/fbi investigations. 
Marcus is our second main character, his story begins by showing us the way he lives and that's by taking care of an old man named Carl but later on something bad unfolds, as Carl's only son intrudes the house while they were gone and tries to steal money from his father.
Kara is our final main character, a father orders this Android so she could be his maid and also take care of his daughter while he isn't at his house or just doing better stuff according to him (red ice). but then something bad happens in the household and this father is so mad because his daughter is not doing as he says, and things unfold very quickly. Kara's story is all about taking care about someone she loves and cares about, and someday be in a much safer place that ain't Detroit.

Gameplay: the gameplay is amazing and astonishing, it makes sense why this was a ps4 title, if you play the game with a mouse and a keyboard you wont get what i'm talking about, but if you play it with either a dualshock or a dualsense you are in for a treat, ain't gonna spoil too much thought.

Graphics: the visuals uuhhhmm, what am i even supposed to say? this game is quite old, it released back in 2018 and this is by far the best lookin game there has been out since then, now it's 2023 and no game yet has managed to look like that, and not even come close to either the visuals or acting

Verdict: Detroit Become Human is a game that is worth every euro you put onto it to buy it, aand trust me! you won't be dissapointed since the game has so many endings, the main story is about 12 hours long when you play it the first time and probably even up to 50 if you do all the endings and achievements.

Strongly recommend this game!!

Detroit Become Human: 10/10

145366957.review:
The premise of Detroit: Become Human's story is founded almost exclusively on some of the most tired, cliched AI and technology tropes in science fiction, and at first glance you may be concerned there's nothing substantive to engage with here. If you can set reservations aside, you'll discover that there's a consistent, well-conceived vision for the game's identity and narrative that will reward players who take the story as seriously as it takes itself.

Detroit's worldbuilding is engrossing, its puzzles and gameplay are satisfying, and most importantly, your choices feel like they truly matter and have a real impact on the way the story unfolds. Personally, I think picking this up when it's on sale is a no-brainer.

The demo is available for free on Steam, and it's basically just the first mission. It's representative of the overall game, so there's no reason to not give it a shot.

145310562.review:
¿Qué ocurriría si las máquinas, que nosotros mismos hemos diseñado y creado, empezaran a ser conscientes de su propia existencia? Nos trasladamos a 2038, en una Detroit donde los androides están al servicio de la sociedad como asistentes o realizando trabajos que personalmente pienso que en el futuro deberían desarrollar las máquinas (camareros, dependientes...). Son seres serviciales, una posible representación y no muy lejana de lo que nos puede deparar como humanidad en un futuro próximo donde la tecnología está avanzando a pasos agigantados.

En Detroit: Become Human nos pondremos en la piel sintética de sus tres protagonistas: Markus, cuidador de un anciano pero reconocido pintor; Kara, asistente personal de Todd, un padre borracho que maltrata a su hija y Connor, un androide de Cyberlife (la empresa que desarrolló dichos androides) que ofrece ayuda a la policía de Detroit en busca de divergentes: androides que están tomando conciencia propia de su existencia y prefieren vivir en libertad que esclavizados por los humanos. Este suceso está siendo cada vez más frecuente y llegará a amenazar la supremacía de la humanidad, ¿podrán dos razas convivir en el planeta?

[h1]8/10[/h1] Sin duda de momento Detroit: Become Human es el mejor juego de Quantic Dream y además lo veo bastante rejugable, ya que en Heavy Rain una vez conoces al asesino pierde su gracia y el Beyond: Two Souls (personalmente no me agradó tanto como el Heavy Rain) lo veo con muy poca posiblidad de decisión. En cambio en el Detroit, una vez finalizado el nivel, puedes ver todas las ramificaciones posibles dentro del nivel, todo lo que podría haber pasado, y algunos escenarios son muy, muy locos, lo que acrecenta el volver a rejugarlo. Recomendadísimo sin duda, además de que plantea cuestiones morales bastante interesantes sobre los humanos y la tecnología.

145290885.review:
---[Gráficos]---
Aunque juegues con configuración en normal, se puede apreciar que este es un apartado que resalta en el videojuego. Los requisitos son altos si es que quieres que se vea de maravilla (así que ten una buena tarjeta gráfica). Si ese no es tu objetivo te bastará con jugar con la configuración en normal para disfrutar de igual manera.

---[Audiencia]---
Recomendado a adolescentes y adultos para poder comprender mejor la historia.

---[Historia]---
Historia bien escrita que te engancha al primer momento al jugarlo. La forma en que entrelaza las historias es muy interesante.

---[Tiempo de Juego]---
Es un juego que para sacarle todo el provecho necesitas interactuar con todo lo que puedes, por ende esto alarga la duración (20-25 horas apróx. necesitas para completarlo).

---[Precio]---
El precio del juego es totalmente válido. La mejor compra que he hecho si se habla de la categoría de videojuegos de elecciones, puesto que tienes una gran cantidad de finales (no solo dos).

---[Bugs]---
Por lo menos al jugar, no vi ningún bug que me arruinara mi experiencia al jugarlo. Ahora bien, si tuve problemas al iniciarlo, puesto que necesitaba actualizar los controladores de la GPU integrada (ojo ahí si no les abre).

---{Puntuación}---
9/10. Principalmente porque no me agrado tanto al jugar como Markus, pero para gustos, colores.

145237295.review:
[b] Detroit: Become Human - A beautifully crafted game of choice and consequence. [/b]

I'm currently writing this review immediately after I finished the game's credits, and it's hard to even know where to begin - I do feel that, after completing a full playthrough of D:BH, I feel completely satisfied with how my choices weaved the game's ending; even if the outcomes experienced by the main characters weren't exactly ideal. In every high-stakes situation, I felt as though the game truly put me in the driver's seat to alter the entire course of events from that point forward. Some consequences of my actions were completely predictable, others caught me by surprise. There were actually moments that I audibly said, "Holy shit, did that actually just happen?", because the choices I made forged an unpredictable branch to move the story along.

On a graphical level, the game is beautiful. I never played D:BH when it first released in 2018, but even at release I was well aware of game media buzzing about its looks. The game has seemingly endless moments that make players get an itchy screenshot finger - my sole 9 hour experience alone pushed me to snap 12, mostly of Markus! I'm sure when I go achievement hunting in the future for 100% completion, I'll rack up more damage to my screenshot folder in that regard.

The game is a bit clunky in some respects, especially when it comes to fidelity of movement. There would be instances where I'd see an opening in a crowd of people, for example, and whichever character I was in control of would proceed to get boxed in by static NPCs. There were player animations that made navigating crowds [i] look [/i] more fluid than what was actually the case. I probably didn't do myself any favours by playing with mouse and keyboard, so I'll definitely be giving controller a try when I pick this up again. The story itself was also clunky in some spots, if that makes sense. A couple of the twists revealed to me in my game felt a bit forced, and I feel like the writing's overall strength took a hit in some areas due to the plethora of outcomes and events that had to be devised by producers. These couple of awkward twists felt like a one-size fits all approach to give every story path its own action/emotional peak, even if one wasn't really required to advance your story.

All in all, I highly recommend this to anyone who is looking for something casual, but not cozy. D:BH's cinematic nature lets the player sit back and watch events unfold in many spots, but it also keeps you on your toes with quicktime events and dialogue timers. The game will constantly make you question the morality of your actions, as well as the actions of those around you in the story. I'm not sure why I waited 5 years after release to pick this up and give it a try, but I'm glad I did - I'm sure you will be glad, too!

145110836.review:
This game is entirely story-based and the story is really weird. David Cage clearly wanted to make some kind of race allegory with the androids but it quickly becomes odd the more you think about it. Androids and Black people are not the same in that the human race did not create black people to be slaves; white people forced slavery upon unwilling Africans who already lived complex lives within organized and complex societies. I don't like the somewhat racist undertones of this allegory, as well-meaning as I'm sure it is.

Also, the game is like "choose whether Marcus will lead a peaceful revolution or a violent one" and then punishes you incessantly for choosing to violently resist your enslavers, which I think is really weird and ham-fisted. Why give me choices in this story if the authors have already decided which ones are morally good and right. Just make the choices for me at this point. 

David Cage is a freak and not a very good writer. This story is freaky and not particularly well-written, and it's the entire game. It's only saving grace is the Connor story, which is really cool and fun, kind of a bladerunner homage, but then is promptly bungled once he gets involved in the other stories.

145088900.review:
At first I thought this was going to be a horrible game to play due to the play mechanics: Press a button to get the character to see what it can interact with or move the mouse a certain way, just to get the character to do something. But a little ways into the game, I noticed that I had a great many choices sometimes for how the game took shape. I could do or not do certain things depending on my choices, and I had a lot of choices I didn't even know I had until the end of a chapter during the review. This is an extremely re-playable game because of that because you can go back and see what difference different choices would have had.

The story you are being told is a really good story too. Not at first but again, a little ways into the game it really picks up. It isn't a "this happens and then that happens" kind of story either. It is a story about valid and deep moral and philosophical choices. It makes you think about why would you want to make certain choices and not others. Sure you could get through this game without thinking, but why would you want to do that?

To make this game even better, you get "bonuses" for playing the game, things like music tracks and videos related to the game story. This just adds to the overall experience.

If this game were made into a movie, it would be an awesome and great movie. I dislike movies in general but if this game were made into a movie, it would be worth it. I would watch it in a theater and I would buy it on Blu-ray, and it would be my first- or second-most favorite movie of all time. In hindsight, I think that wouldn't be possible since it would go against the purpose of the game to allow different endings for different choices.

There is a problem with this game though, the problem being the unspoken philosophical rule that to be "just a machine" is inferior to being human. The authors of the game imply that empathy is a feeling and machines cannot have feelings, and that only humans can have feelings (and by logical extension therefore animals cannot have feelings). But humans evolved from animals and there is nothing that humans have that animals don't also have a template for us having, including feelings of empathy. Sure much of what animals have is more rudimentary than it is in humans, but nevertheless it is there. Evolution is logical and non-randomly results in the mechanical progression of life built upon what came before it, so in a way, animals and humans are biological machines. So what is wrong with being "just a machine" then? So I have a problem HONESTLY answering any questions in the game related to being "just a machine" because it can't be done.

145052352.review:
[h1] If you can tolerate QTEs, it's a real treat [/h1] This is the first game I’ve played from Quantic Dream, and I’m glad I also have Heavy Rain and Beyond: Two Souls sitting in my backlog because this was excellent. I’ve seen it described as either a game you watch or a movie you play and I don’t necessarily disagree with that statement, but I do disagree with the negative connotation sometimes attached to it. I can see why some people may feel it's not game-y enough, but that’s like complaining that books don’t have good soundtracks. 

Detroit: Become Human is essentially a 10-15 hour blockbuster-calibre, interactive drama centred around the philosophy and morality of artificial intelligence coexisting with humanity. The cast, acting and script is incredible, the branching paths and narrative is intelligent and meaningful, the characters are engaging and the story is thought-provoking, emotional and gripping the whole way through. The only drawback is messing up a QTE can sometimes lock you out of a choice you wanted to make.
